messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:17): hm, misspelt words is an interesting use case for <u>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:17): has that ever been brought up before? i don't recall seeing it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:17): (listed in the CP for <u>)
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (22:18): doesn't recall seeing it

8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:21): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, personally, I like the idea, but due to the use of INS and DEL, wouldn't a new tag such as UNS (unsure) be more appropriate? -- new name needed, but it would apply to text that may be wrong (either caught misspelling in a WYSIWYG or a piece of quoted text that was loosely quoted and may not be exact)
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:21): Mainly because <u> already has such a history of being strictly underline
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:22): i dunno, i haven't studied how common it is for web pages to indicate spelling mistakes
8925426ae91d6282f262eb2ee108bdc0 (22:23): Well, I think the spelling mistakes side of the tag would be more for WYSIWYG editors, not so much the final version of the page.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:23): Like in static content, or dynamic spellchecking in text entry fields?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:23): anywhere they'd use an element, i guess

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (22:25): I don't think I've ever seen it in static content, except maybe when people were talking about the Word spelling/grammar checker and using it demonstratively (in which case they don't want arbitrary underline-like styling, they want the precise colour and shape that Word uses)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:26): yeah
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:48): yay http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/76115 (onformchange and friends)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:49): yeah, Companion Specifications is an odd name
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:49): yeah, Companion Specifications is an odd name
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:49): Specs TODO
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:50): So, why is html5lib outputting &NonBreakingSpace; instead of &nbsp;?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:50): so does webkit's window.onerror impl support <script>onerror=function(){alert('woot')}</script><script>for(;) { lol syntax error</script> ?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:50): or just uncaught exceptions?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:51): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: because it's earlier in the entities table, maybe?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:51): noticed that web dom core switched from &copy; to &COPY; in its output
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (22:52): Installing html5lib tip wasn't a good idea, apparently

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:52): I wonder how these comments work. First positive, then negative, now positive again. I guess incoming link from a positive article invites positive comments and incoming link from a negative article invites negative comments?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:53): maybe html5lib should have a separate entity table for the serializer where COPY and NonBreakingSpace are not present
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:54): or in some other way have the serializer output nbsp and copy instead
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:54): the serializer should only need five entries
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (22:55): what if you want ascii-only and don't like NCRs?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:57): haha
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (22:57): once you get arguments like "Stealing content was never easier than with HTML5" you know the debate is over

4c681049601b3c374f1d2c0077c99049 (23:01): "Sorry, @onchange, I wasn't talking to you. Collision of microsyntaxes!"

8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:04): You want curies, for the 140-char limit
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:04): With predefined prefixes.
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:05): In an OWL file you reference from your profile

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:08): in the sense that it is part of the "Registries" collection
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (23:08): hmm, apple.com uses SVG with <path>s as a background image for text in the navbar? boo. why don't they use real text + css text-shadow?
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:09): That would work in other browsers?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:09): It woudl work in Safari.  Why would they care about everyone else?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:09): (And yes, text-shadow has pretty good support.)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:09): why wouldn't SVG work in other browsers?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (23:10): Also, 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81, we were wondering who you were this morning.  I was convinced you were a Moz employee.

e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173 (23:10): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: for serialisation (expressed as xslt2 maps)  in the entities spec I omit all the aliases, so nbsp and copy win over the others, easy enough to generate a list of unique entity names from unicode.xml (basically just omit mmlalias and html5-uppercase entity sets0
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:10): Moz volunteer, atm
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (23:10): SVG as background images seems less widely supported than text-shadow
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (23:10): hopes that svg background image has an intrinsic height and width
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:10): yeah I guess that's true
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (23:10): Otherwise you earn a hardblocker, 8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 :)
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (23:10): but it's better than some -webkit thing :-)
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (23:10): because otherwise they might be hosing themselves, as no browsers implement lack of width right
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (23:11): 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: I have the patch close to plausibly done :-)
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (23:11): the algorithm is a mess of complexity, tho
8c8837db54a2907cacd8633547977e33 (23:11): if it had to block, I could finish it for then
